  50      """ 
  51      Graphs and hypergraphs are implemented differently, so even though hypergraphs are a

  55      This abstract class contains those few methods which are sufficiently abstract to work

  59 -    def reachable(self,a,s): 

  60          """Return all vertices not in C{a} to which there is a path from a vertex in C{a} 
  61          which includes no vertices in C{s} 
  62   
  63          'Vertices' in C{s} which are not in the hypergraph/graph are silently ignored. 
  64   
  65          @param a: Set of vertices 
  66          @type a: Iterable 
  67          @param s: Blocking set of vertices 
  68          @type s: Iterable 
  69          @return: Vertices not in C{a} reachable from C{a} by a path avoiding C{s} 
  70          @rtype: List 
  71          @raise ValueError: If C{a} and C{s} are not disjoint 
  72          @raise KeyError: If C{a} contains a non-existent vertex 
  73          """ 
  74          banned = set(s) 
  75          if banned.intersection(a): 
  76              raise ValueError("Sets are not disjoint") 
  77          banned.update(a) 
  78          frontier = list(a) 
  79          reachable = [] 
  80          while frontier: 
  81              new_vertices = self.neighbours(frontier.pop()) - banned 
  82              reachable.extend(new_vertices) 
  83              frontier.extend(new_vertices) 
  84              banned.update(new_vertices) 
  85          return reachable

  88 -    def separates(self,a,b,s): 

  89          """Return whether C{s} separates C{a} from C{b} in C{self} 
  90   
  91          'Vertices' in C{s} which are not in the graph/hypergraph are silently ignored. 
  92   
  93          @param a: Set of vertices 
  94          @type a: Iterable 
  95          @param b: Set of vertices 
  96          @type b: Iterable 
  97          @param s: Set of vertices possibly separating C{a} from C{b} 
  98          @type s: Iterable 
  99          @return: Whether C{s} separates C{a} from C{b} 
 100          @rtype: Boolean 
 101          @raise ValueError: If C{a}, C{b} and C{s} are not disjoint 
 102          @raise KeyError: If C{a} or C{b} contain a non-existent vertex 
 103          """ 
 104          a, b, s = set(a), set(b), frozenset(s) 
 105          if len(a|b|s) != len(a) + len(b) + len(s): 
 106              raise ValueError("Sets are not disjoint") 
 107          a_open, b_open = list(a), list(b) 
 108          a_seen, b_seen = a|s, b|s 
 109          while a_open: 
 110              new_vertices = self.neighbours(a_open.pop(0)) - a_seen 
 111              if new_vertices & b: 
 112                  return False 
 113              a_seen.update(new_vertices) 
 114              a.update(new_vertices) 
 115              a_open.extend(new_vertices) 
 116              a, b = b, a 
 117              a_open, b_open = b_open, a_open 
 118              a_seen, b_seen = b_seen, a_seen 
 119          return True

 122 -class HyperGraph(_Incidence): 

 123      """A hypergraph is a collection of hyperedges. A hyperedge is a set of vertices. 
 124   
 125      The base set is defined implicitly as the union of the hyperedges. 
 126      @ivar _hyperedges: The distinct hyperedges in the hypergraph. Each hyperedge is a frozenset 
 127      @type _hyperedges: Set 
 128      @ivar _star: Maps a vertex to the set of hyperedges which 
 129      contain it. (Effectively represents the I{dual} hypergraph.) 
 130      @type _star: Dictionary 
 131      @ivar _extras: If repeated hyperedges exist, maps each repeated hyperedge to the 
 132      number of times it is repeated. (If repeated once, the hyperedge occurs twice.) 
 133      @type _extras: Dictionary 
 134      """

 374   
 375           @todo: make more efficient

 380           for i, h in enumerate(self.hyperedges()):

 394 -    def grahams(self): 

 395          """Run Graham's algorithm on a hypergraph 
 396   
 397          If the hypergraph is decomposable then upon return C{self} is either 
 398          empty or contains a single empty hyperedge. 
 399          """ 
 400          if self.is_empty(): 
 401              return self 
 402           
 403          self.red() 
 404   
 405          cardinality = {} 
 406          sets = [set()] 
 407          max = 0 
 408          for vertex, star in self._star.items(): 
 409              card = len(star) - 1 
 410              cardinality[vertex] = card 
 411              if card > max: 
 412                  for i in range(card-max): 
 413                      sets.append(set()) 
 414                  max = card 
 415              sets[card].add(vertex) 
 416               
 417          while sets[0] != set(): 
 418              new_hs = self.remove_vertices(sets[0]) 
 419              sets[0] = set() 
 420              for hyperedge in new_hs: 
 421                  if self.is_redundant(hyperedge): 
 422                      self.remove_hyperedge_once(hyperedge) 
 423                      for vertex in hyperedge: 
 424                          card = cardinality[vertex] 
 425                          sets[card].remove(vertex) 
 426                          card -= 1 
 427                          cardinality[vertex] = card 
 428                          sets[card].add(vertex) 
 429          return self

 641 -    def is_reduced(self): 

 642          """Test whether a hypergraph is reduced 
 643   
 644          @return: Whether a hypergraph is reduced 
 645          @rtype: Boolean 
 646          """ 
 647          if self._hyperedges == set(): 
 648              return True 
 649          if hasattr(self,'_extras'): 
 650              return False 
 651          if emptyset in self._hyperedges: 
 652              if len(self._hyperedges) > 1: 
 653                  return False 
 654              else: 
 655                  return True

 700 -    def is_separating(self): 

 701          """Whether the hypergraph is a separating hypergraph

 703          A hypergraph is separating if, for every vertex v, the intersection 
 704          of all hyperedges in v's star equals {v} 
 705   
 706          @return: Whether the hypergraph is a separating hypergraph 
 707          @rtype: Boolean 
 708          """

 711              st = tmp.pop() 
 712              while len(st) > 1: 
 713                  try: 
 714                      st &= tmp.pop() 
 715                  except KeyError: 
 716                      return False 
 717          return True

 770 -    def join_forest_ve(self): 

 771          """Return a join forest for the hypergraph using vertex elimination 
 772   
 773          Source is annotated. 
 774          Refs:: 
 775           
 776            @TechReport{graham79, 
 777             author =      {M. H. Graham}, 
 778             title =       {On the universal relation}, 
 779             institution =  {University of Toronto}, 
 780             year =        1979, 
 781             address =     {Toronto, Canada} 
 782           } 
 783   
 784           @article{322389, 
 785           author = {Catriel Beeri and Ronald Fagin and David Maier and Mihalis Yannakakis}, 
 786           title = {On the Desirability of Acyclic Database Schemes}, 
 787            journal = {Journal of the  {ACM}}, 
 788            volume = {30}, 
 789            number = {3}, 
 790            year = {1983}, 
 791            issn = {0004-5411}, 
 792            pages = {479--513}, 
 793            doi = {http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2402.322389}, 
 794            publisher = {ACM Press}, 
 795            address = {New York, NY, USA}, 
 796           } 
 797   
 798          @return: A join forest for the hypergraph 
 799          @rtype: L{UForest} 
 800          @raise RedundancyError: If hypergraph is not reduced 
 801          @raise ValueError: If the hypergraph is reduced but not decomposable 
 802          """ 
 803   
 804          # Graham's algorithm is as follows: 
 805          # Apply the following two operations until neither applies: 
 806          # 1. Delete a vertex that it is in only one hyperedge 
 807          # 2. Delete a redundant hyperedge 
 808          # If the hypergraph is decomposable all vertices will eventually be deleted. 
 809   
 810          # Beeri et al show that Graham's algorithm can be used to construct 
 811          # a join tree from a decomposable hypergraph. The vertices of the join tree are the 
 812          # hyperedges of the hypergraph. If a non-empty hyperedge is deleted at step 2 of Graham's algorithm 
 813          # then, in the join tree, an edge is drawn between it and one of the hyperedges containing it. 
 814   
 815          # This method implements this approach. The only difference from Graham's algorithm 
 816          # is that in step 1 all 'isolated' vertices in the selected hyperedge are removed. Only 
 817          # once this is done is there any prospect of the hyperedge being redundant. 
 818   
 819          # Since hyperedges will be altered we set up 'state' (lines 1-3) which maps hyperedges 
 820          # from their (immutable) initial state to their 
 821          # (mutable) current state. If a hyperedge is deleted it is removed from 'state'. 
 822          # In lines 4-11 is set up the mapping 'in_only_one'. A hyperedge is a key in this mapping if it 
 823          # contains a vertex which appears in no other edges (an 'isolated' vertex). 
 824          # The value associated with this key is 
 825          # just the set of vertices only appearing in the hyperedge. If a vertex appears in more than one 
 826          # hyperedge, we record how many in the mapping 'cardinality'. 
 827   
 828          # The join forest is initialised to have the hyperedges as vertices, and no edges at line 12. 
 829   
 830          # The main loop is executed as long as there is a vertex contained in only one edge (line 13). 
 831   
 832          # A hyperedge containing vertices not found elsewhere is selected and these vertices are 
 833          # then deleted from it (lines 14-16). If residual vertices exist in the hyperedge (line 17), we 
 834          # need to check for redundancy. Lines 18-25 do this by constructing 'proper_supersets': the set of 
 835          # remaining (line 21) hyperedges containing all vertices in 'residue'. 
 836          # If (line 26) this is non-empty, then the hyperedge is removed (line 27) and an arbitrary 
 837          # member of proper_supersets is chosen for the required connection in the join tree (line 28). 
 838          # If a hyperedge has been removed it is necessary to update 'in_only_one' 
 839          # and 'cardinality' appropriately (lines 30-35). 
 840   
 841          # Lines 36,37: If there were no residual vertices then the hyperedge has become empty. 
 842          # So, if there are 
 843          # any other remaining hyperedges, it will be redundant, but no join forest edges need be drawn. 
 844   
 845          # Termination: If there remain undeleted edges (and hence undeleted vertices) then the hypergraph 
 846          # was not decomposable (lines 38,39) 
 847          # otherwise all is well and the join forest can be returned (line 40). 
 848          if not self.is_reduced(): 
 849              raise RedundancyError("%s is not reduced" % self) 
 850           
 851          def add_to_set(dkt,key,member): 
 852              try: 
 853                  dkt[key].add(member) 
 854              except KeyError: 
 855                  dkt[key] = set([member]) 

 856   
 857          state = {}                               # 1 
 858          for hyperedge in self._hyperedges:       # 2 
 859              state[hyperedge] = set(hyperedge)    # 3 
 860          cardinality = {}                                                       # 4 
 861          in_only_one = {}                                                       # 5 
 862          for vertex, hyperedges in self._star.items():  # 6 
 863              nh = len(hyperedges)                                               # 7 
 864              if nh == 1:                                                        # 8 
 865                  add_to_set(in_only_one,member(hyperedges),vertex)              # 9 
 866              else:                                                              #10 
 867                  cardinality[vertex] = nh                                       #11 
 868          join_forest = UForest(self._hyperedges)  # 12 
 869          while in_only_one:    # 13 
 870              hyperedge, vertices = in_only_one.popitem()  # 14 
 871              residue = state[hyperedge]                   # 15 
 872              residue -= vertices                          # 16 
 873              if residue:              # 17 
 874                  cp = residue.copy()                                                         # 18 
 875                  v = cp.pop()                                                                # 19 
 876                  proper_supersets = self._star[v] - set([hyperedge]) # 20 
 877                  proper_supersets.intersection(state)                                        # 21 
 878                  for vertex in cp:                                                           # 22 
 879                      proper_supersets &= self._star[vertex]          # 23 
 880                      if not proper_supersets:                                                # 24 
 881                          break                                                               # 25 
 882                  if proper_supersets:                          # 26 
 883                      del state[hyperedge]                      # 27 
 884                      receiver = member(proper_supersets)       # 28 
 885                      join_forest.put_line(hyperedge,receiver)  # 29 
 886                      for vertex in residue:                           # 30 
 887                          nh = cardinality[vertex]                     # 31 
 888                          if nh == 2:                                  # 32 
 889                              add_to_set(in_only_one,receiver,vertex)  # 33 
 890                          else:                                        # 34 
 891                              cardinality[vertex] = nh - 1             # 35 
 892              else:                     # 36 
 893                  del state[hyperedge]  # 37 
 894          if state:                                                                           # 38 
 895              raise ValueError("Hypergraph was not decomposable, no join forest is possible") # 39 
 896          return join_forest # 40

1722 -    def reduction(self): 

1723          """Apply the 'Reduction Algorithm' of Tarjan and Yannakakis 
1724   
1725          SIAM J Computing 13 (1984) 566-579 
1726          On return C{self} will be the I{reduction} of the original C{self}. 
1727          Despite the name, this is not the same as reducing the hypergraph by 
1728          removing redundant hyperedges. 
1729          @return: The removed hyperedges 
1730          @rtype: List 
1731          """ 
1732          removed = [] 
1733          while True: 
1734              for vertex, hyperedges in self._star.items(): 
1735                  if len(hyperedges) == 1: 
1736                      hyperedge = member(hyperedges) # only 1 member 
1737                      self.remove_hyperedge(hyperedge) 
1738                      new_hyperedge = hyperedge - set([vertex]) 
1739                      try: 
1740                          self.add_hyperedge(new_hyperedge) 
1741                      except RedundancyError: 
1742                          removed.append(new_hyperedge) 
1743                      break 
1744              else: 
1745                  return removed

3709 -    def maximum_cardinality_search(self,choose=None): 

3710          """Return maximum cardinality search 
3711   
3712          Ref:: 
3713   
3714           @Article{tarjan84:_simpl, 
3715           author =        {Robert E. Tarjan and Mihalis Yannakakis}, 
3716           title =         {Simple linear-time algorithms to test chordality of graphs, test acyclicity of hypergraphs, and selectively reduce acyclic hypergraphs},  
3717           journal =       {{SIAM} Journal of Computing}, 
3718           year =          1984, 
3719           volume =        13, 
3720           number =        3, 
3721           pages =         {566--579}, 
3722           month =         {August} 
3723          """ 
3724   
3725          # As Tarjan and Yannakakis put it the basic idea is: 
3726          # "Number the vertices from n to 1 in decreasing order. As the next 
3727          # vertex to number, select the vertex adjacent to the largest number 
3728          # of previously numbered vertices, breaking ties arbitrarily". 
3729   
3730          # The following implements their algorithm, execpt that numbering is from 
3731          # n-1 to 0, and the user can specify a tie-breaker (the 'choose' function) 
3732          # if desired. 
3733   
3734          # Lines 1-12 are initialisation. The key data structure is the dictionary 
3735          # 'cardinality' which throughout maps each unnumbered vertex to the number of 
3736          # numbered vertices adjacent to it. The list 'sets' is such that sets[i] 
3737          # is a set containing all unnumbered vertices with cardinality i. Initially no vertices 
3738          # are numbered so all vertices have cardinality zero (lines 7 and 10). 
3739          # alpha and alpha_inv will contain the vertex numbering on return. alpha maps 
3740          # each vertex to its number, and alpha_inv is just the inverse mapping (see lines 
3741          # 17 and 18). Eventually all the None values in alpha_inv (line 9) will be replaced 
3742          # by the appropriate integers. j is the largest value such that sets[j] is non-empty. 
3743   
3744          # Line 9a adds a dummy empty set so that j in line 24 never causes an IndexError 
3745   
3746          # In the main loop (lines 13-26) we number vertices from i=n-1 down to i=0 
3747          # (The 'range' function (13) generates a list with precisely this sequence of integers.) 
3748          # The loop invariant is that 'cardinality', 'sets' and 'j' maintain the 
3749          # properties described above. In particular, 
3750          # sets[j] contains all unnumbered vertices with maximum cardinality. 
3751   
3752          # Line 14 assigns v to be a maximum cardinality vertex and removes it 
3753          # from sets[j]. This assignment is then stored (lines 15,16) 
3754   
3755          # Now that v has been numbered the cardinalities of all its unnumbered

3883 -    def triangulate(self,elimination_order,zero_fillin_check=False,modify=True): 

3884          """Triangulate the graph using C{elimination_order} 
3885   
3886          Alters C{self} by default 
3887   
3888          Ref:: 
3889   
3890           @Article{tarjan84:_simpl, 
3891           author =        {Robert E. Tarjan and Mihalis Yannakakis}, 
3892           title =         {Simple linear-time algorithms to test chordality of graphs, test acyclicity of hypergraphs, and selectively reduce acyclic hypergraphs},  
3893           journal =       {{SIAM} Journal of Computing}, 
3894           year =          1984, 
3895           volume =        13, 
3896           number =        3, 
3897           pages =         {566--579}, 
3898           month =         {August} 
3899           
3900          @param elimination_order: The elimination order 
3901          @type elimination_order: An iterator (typically a list) 
3902          @param zero_fillin_check: If set the method returns whether C{elimination_order} is a zero 
3903          fill-in and does not alter C{self} 
3904          @type zero_fillin_check: Boolean 
3905          @param modify: Whether to add the fill-in edges to C{self} 
3906          @type modify: Boolean 
3907          @return: (As long as C{zero_fillin_check=False}), the fill-in (added edges) produced by C{elimination_order} 
3908          @rtype: (As long as C{zero_fillin_check=False}), the list of tuples, each tuple is an unordered pair of vertices 
3909          """ 
3910          # This algorithm exploits the notion of a vertex's 
3911          # *follower*. The follower of vertex v is the earliest vertex 
3912          # in the elimination order coming after v which is adjacent to 
3913          # v in the elimination graph (i.e. the graph formed by adding 
3914          # the fill-in edges). A vertex need not have a follower - the 
3915          # last vertex never has one. 
3916   
3917          # Define f*(x) to be the {x, f(x), f(f(x)), ... }, ie the path 
3918          # of followers starting with x. Theorem 3 of the above 
3919          # reference establishes the following. If v comes before w in 
3920          # the elimination ordering then there is a v-w edge in the 
3921          # elimination graph if and only if there is a vertex x which 
3922          # is (i) adjacent to w in the orginal graph and (ii) where v 
3923          # is a member of f*(x) 
3924   
3925          # This result leads to the following algorithm. The vertices 
3926          # are processed in order.  For each vertex w the neighbours 
3927          # which come before w are considered.  For each of these 
3928          # neighbours x, the vertices in f*(x) coming before w are 
3929          # found and connected to w. 
3930   
3931          # A variant of this is implemented as follows. Dictionary f 
3932          # stores the `follower' mapping and the list fill_in records 
3933          # fill-in edges. They are initialised in lines 1 and 
3934          # 2. Vertices w are considered according to the given order 
3935          # (line 3). 
3936   
3937          # A dummy value of w for the follower of w is assigned (line 
3938          # 4). self._ne[w] on line 5 is the set of neighbours of w. By 
3939          # intersecting this with the dictionary f the variable 
3940          # `earlier_neighbours' contains only neighbours of w earlier 
3941          # in the elimination order. The set `done' (of which more 
3942          # later) is these neighbours together with w. 
3943   
3944          # Each earlier neighbour x is considered in turn (line 7). If 
3945          # the follower of x has yet to be found then f[x] in line 8 is 
3946          # x otherwise it is the follower of x. In the latter case, the 
3947          # chain of followers of x are considered (lines 9-13) until we 
3948          # hit one that has already been `done'. Any vertex in such a 
3949          # chain is a follower of an earlier neighbour of w which is 
3950          # not itself an existing neighbour of w and so a fill-in edge 
3951          # is needed (line 11). x at line 11 cannot be an existing 
3952          # neighbour since all earlier neighbours are in the set `done' 
3953          # and x is not (line 9) and all later neighbours cannot be 
3954          # reached yet by a chain of followers. Note that the set 
3955          # `done' also prevents revisiting sequences of followers due 
3956          # to line 10. Lines 9a and 9b provide an early exit if all that 
3957          # is required is a check for a zero fill-in. 
3958   
3959          # If the x at the end of one of these chains is found to 
3960          # contain a dummy value for its follower this is replaced by 
3961          # the true value - w - in lines 13-14. 
3962   
3963          # Lines 16-18 add the fill-in edges to the graph (if that is 
3964          # required) and return the fillin-edges. Lines 14a and 14b return 
3965          # the appropriate boolean value if a check is being done. 
3966           
3967          f = {}          # 1 
3968          fill_in = []    # 2 
3969          for w in elimination_order:                          # 3 
3970              f[w] = w                                         # 4 
3971              earlier_neighbours = self._ne[w].intersection(f) # 5 
3972              done = set([w]) | earlier_neighbours             # 6 
3973              for x in earlier_neighbours:           #  7 
3974                  x = f[x]                           #  8 
3975                  while x not in done:               #  9 
3976                      if zero_fillin_check:            #  9a 
3977                          return False                 #  9b 
3978                      done.add(x)                    # 10 
3979                      fill_in.append((x,w))          # 11 
3980                      x = f[x]                       # 12 
3981                  if f[x] == x:                      # 13 
3982                      f[x] = w                       # 14 
3983          if zero_fillin_check:                         # 14a 
3984              return True                               # 14b 
3985          if modify:                   # 15 
3986              self.put_lines(fill_in)  # 16 
3987          return fill_in               # 17

4253 -    def _bbsect(bb,origin): 

4254          """Gets intersection of bounding box and a line. 
4255   
4256          Given a line drawn between the centre of a rectangle 
4257          and some other point, finds the intersection of that line 
4258          and the rectangle's boundary. 
4259          This is used to prevent arcs overwriting the text which 
4260          represents a node. 
4261          @param bb: Bounding box 
4262          @type bb: Tuple 
4263          @param origin: Origin of line 
4264          @type origin: Tuple 
4265          """ 
4266          (x1,y1,x2,y2) = bb 
4267          (x,y) = origin 
4268          x_m, y_m = (x1+x2)/2.0, (y1+y2)/2.0            # find rectangle centre 
4269          if x < x_m:                                    # perform reflections:  
4270              x1,x2 = x2,x1                              #  so that afterwards we can 
4271          if y < y_m:                                  #  pretend (almost) that intersection is in  
4272              y1,y2 = y2,y1                              #  top right quadrant of rectangle 
4273          try: 
4274              g = (y-y_m)/(x-x_m)                        # get gradient of line 
4275          except ZeroDivisionError:                      # if gradient infinite: 
4276              return x_m,y2                              #  intersection due north of centre 
4277          if abs(g) > abs((y2-y1+0.0)/(x2-x1)):          # compare g to gradient of diagonal: 
4278              return x_m+(y2-y_m)/g, y2                  #  (abs needed since we may have reflected) 
4279          else:                                          #  if g greater then intersection at top 
4280              return x2, y_m+g*(x2-x_m)                  #  else it's at the side

5433          """Compute a vector of expected values from a '.sample' file 
5434   
5435          It is up to the functions in C{fns} to understand what the integers 
5436          mean 
5437           
5438          """ 
5439          result = [0] * len(fns)

5443              families = [int(x) for x in items[1:]] 
5444              for i, fn in enumerate(fns):

6224      """Class for representing approximations to probability

6227   
6228      An instance is essentially a sample (i.e. a set) of ADGs, each 
6229      labelled with its probability up to a multiplicative normalising 
6230      factor. The sum of these probabilities is also stored. By 
6231      approximating the probability of each ADG not in the sample by 0, an estimate 
6232      of the probability of all those present in sample can be easily found. 
6233   
6234      Each ADG is representing by a tuple of parent sets, one parent set 
6235      for each variable. The parent sets in the tuple are ordered 
6236      according to the lexicographic order of the variables. 
6237   
6238      Store first ADG and then subsequent ADGs are indicated by which family changes. 
6239

6243      @type _probsum: Float
